column4: yesterday while i had an external HDD connected, and data being transferred without any problems there was a power failure. Since then whenever i connect the HDD the hotplugin(automount) point to the local HDD and when i try to manually mount /dev/sdb1 the prompt shows up I/O error, even though the disk is getting mounted perfectly on a mac machine.
this is the error message that shows up when trying to mount using sudo mount -t ntfs /dev/sdb1 external/ http://paste.ubuntu.com/97365/
is there no way to fix this problem..without going to windows?
you can force it to mount, but it's possible you'll lose data because you didnt unmount it properly in windows
i tried doing that...but http://paste.ubuntu.com/97365/ is what it shows
you should never ever just unplug a disk without cleanly unmounting it. there is always a chance that doing so will lose or corrupt some or all of the data.
it's not guaranteed to happen, but it's a chance not worth taking
i understand that...but it happened inadvertently
but then what should i try to do?
and that happens even after you use "-o force" in your mount command?
you know when you shut down windows wrong and it does that thing when it checks the whole disk to make sure nothing's lost? you just need to do that.
but i thought, there's some way in linux as well, to fix it..without going to windows, i.e. linux equivalent of chkdisk or something
we have fsck but it's for linux filesystems, not for windows ones
